titleStmt.title: Truth's triumph over errour: or, The routing of the seven false prophets who have all lived in London in lesse then these 20. years: (viz.) Farnam, Bull, weavers, Robbins, Garment husbandmen. Smith, a shooe-maker. Muggleton and Reeve, taylors. Wherein is clearly discovered and confuted all their most blasphemous, damnable, false and rediculous tenents. Themselves and falshoods opened, anatomized, and dissected, and found to be no better then impostures, liers, deluders, and spirituall gypsies. Proved by time the mother of truth, reason, scripture, and their own contradictions. Written by Stephen Proud-love, a lover of the truth.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

Farnam, Bull, weavers, Robbins, Garment husbandmen. Smith, a shooe-maker. Muggleton and Reeve, taylors. Wherein is clearly discovered and confuted all their most blasphemous, damnable, false and rediculous tenents. Themselves and falshoods opened, anatomized, and dissected, and found to be no better then impostures, liers, deluders, and spirituall gypsies. Proved by time the mother of truth, reason, scripture, and their own contradictions. Written by Stephen Proud-love, a lover of the truth.

notesStmt.note: Caption title on p. 1: A true relation and description of seven pretended prophets, and their false and blasphemous tenets, which have lived, and been iu the City of London, all of them within lesse then these twenty years.
Copy stained with some loss of text.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Truth's Triumph over Errour: OR, The Routing of the Seven fal≈øe PROPHETS, Who have all lived in London in le≈ø≈øe then the≈øe 20. Years: (VIZ.)
Wherein is clearly di≈øcovered and confuted all their mo≈øt Bla≈øphemous, damnable, fal≈øe and rediculous Tenents.
Them≈øelves and Fal≈øhoods opened, Anatomized, and di≈ø≈øected, and found to be no better then Impo≈øtures, Liers, Deluders, and Spirituall Gyp≈øies.
Proved by Time the Mother of Truth, Rea≈øon, Scriptvre, and their own Contradictions.

q.p: Beware of fal≈øe Prophets, which come to you in ≈øheeps cloathing, but inwardly are ravening Wolves.

div.p: Written by Stephen Proud-love, a Lover of the Truth.
LONDON, Printed by J. C. & T. W. for Tho. Lambert, 1653.

div.head: THE EPISTLE TO The READER.
div.p: COurteous Reader, I that am the lea≈øt of the ≈øervants of Love, yet through that little faith in the Love, I have taken upon me to lay open the greate≈øt and horridde≈øt bla≈øphemy again≈øt the God of Love, that (in my under≈øtanding) ever was broached ≈øince man had a being, the very thoughts whereof maketh my heart to tremble, and my ≈øoule as it were to go backwards, according to that ≈øpeech, in the 9th of Jer. ver≈øe 1. Oh that my head were a well of water, and mine eyes a fountaine of tears. &c.

Therefore I do de≈øire loving Friends and Readers, that yee would be plea≈øed to judge ≈øo favourably of all things herein contained, as it is declared in the ≈øimplicity and innocency of the Authours ≈øpirit, and not out of any malice or envy; for here I take the eternall God to witne≈ø≈øe, that I am free from all manner of ≈øpleene again≈øt any party that is herein concerned, only de≈øiring in the love of God, according to the ≈ømall talent, or gift given me from God, to lay open to the world the≈øe Tenets, which may be as dangers, or ≈øtumbling blocks to the weak, onely for that end they may ≈øhun them, and ≈øeeke for a ≈øtability where it is to
be found, even in our God, where all things, and all ≈øecurity el≈øe is to be found; and what≈øoever I ≈øhall here in≈øert, I ≈øhall be able to make good from ≈øeverall witne≈ø≈øes, as from ≈øeverall of their owne di≈øciples, as al≈øo ≈øome whom they have cur≈øed, and ≈øome whom they have neither ble≈ø≈øed, nor cur≈øed. And this I ≈øhall oblige my ≈øelfe to make good at the de≈øire of any ≈øhall require it, who ≈øhall at all times find me at my dwelling, if they will be plea≈øed to inquire for Stephen Proud love, in French Alley in Golding-lane.

div.head: A TRUE RELATION AND De≈øcription of ≈øeven pretended Prophets, and their fal≈øe and Bla≈øphemous Tenets, which have lived, and been in the City of London, all of them within le≈ø≈øe then the≈øe twenty years.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt two that I have knowne in the above≈øayd time, were two Weavers by trade, who≈øe Names were, the one Bull, and the other Farnam, who pretended, and called them≈øelves, the la≈øt Prophets, or the two witne≈ø≈øes, of whom mention is made in Revel. 11. who did declare; That they had power to ≈øtop the heavens that it ≈øhould not raine, and likewi≈øe when it was their plea≈øure to pray againe, the heavens ≈øhould be opened, and ≈øhould ≈øend forth her raine. Secondly, that no Magi≈øtrate ≈øhould have power over their bodies, neither ≈øhould any one kill them by violence. Thirdly, that they ≈øhould live to ≈øee the ≈øacking of Jeru≈øalem. Fourthly, Farnam had a boy whom they affirmed ≈øhould beat a Drumme at the ≈øacking thereof. Fiftly, that Je≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhould have a temporall Monarchy here upon earth, and both the≈øe held the≈øe hereticall Tenets, and did firmely believe that it
≈øhould be ≈øo, but time that manife≈øts all truthes, hath clearly evidenced to the world their falla≈øies, and therefore I need not to make any larger de≈øcription of them, ≈øeeing they are long ≈øince dead by the plague, when they were both pri≈øoners, which was the ju≈øt Judgment of God upon them for their ba≈øe deceivable qualities. And therefore I conclude the≈øe, and ≈øo go on to the next.

The ≈øecond two pretended Prophets, is John Robbins; and Jo≈øeph Garment, who are both yet alive; who did declare that they were God, and had power to rai≈øe the dead: and ≈øecondly, by the clapping of their hands, they were able to ≈øtrike with death whom≈øoever they plea≈øed; and thirdly, that they were to be the Jews deliverers; fourthly, that they were able to divide the waters; fiftly, that they ≈øhould go to Jeru≈øalem, with above a hundred thou≈øand people, whom they ≈øhould convoy thither, with many other rediculous and hereticall tenets, not worthy the mentioning; and therefore I conclude, and go on to the next.

The next pretended Prophet, is one Smith by name, and a ≈øhoemaker by trade, who liveth in the County of Su≈ø≈øex, at a town called Tillington, and he doth declare; fir≈øt, that he held the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt by the hand, for the ≈øpace ‚Ä¢ f five houres together, with whom he had ≈øeveral di≈øco ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
≈øes all that time; ≈øecondly, that he had received o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ from the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, to make a new ≈øort of Paper without any ≈øize, whereupon he ≈øhould cau≈øe the Bible to be reprinted for its pre≈øervation; thirdly, that upon New-yeares day la≈øt there ≈øhould be a general re≈øurrection of all the bea≈øts, and that they ≈øhould come terribly upon the Earth to claim their skins of mankind, and whom≈øoever they ≈øhould finde their skins upon, they would de≈øtroy with de≈øperate violence, with many other fooli≈øh ab≈øurdities, not worth the relating.

div.head: A De≈øcription of the la≈øt two pretended Prophets, and their Tenents.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt whereof is John Reve by name, and a Taylour by trade, the other Lodowick Muggleton a Tailour al≈øo,
both living neer unto the ≈øigne of the Owle in Trinity lane in London; the fir≈øt of the≈øe, John Reve doth declare, that in the beginning of February la≈øt was twelve moneth, he received a commi≈ø≈øion from God, by voice of words, and that Lodowick Muggleton was given unto him to bee his mouth, as Aaron was to Moy≈øes, and that they both together were commi≈ø≈øionated to go forth and declare unto this bloudy world, (as they call it) what every ones e≈øtate and condition was, & who≈øoever they ≈øhould pronounce the ≈øentence of damnation unto, ≈øhould be damned to all eternity, and their e≈øtates bla≈øted; and whoever they ≈øhould pronounce to be ble≈ø≈øed, or ≈øaved, ≈øhould be partakers of Salvation, and that to all eternity; by means wherof, like crafty foulers they caught ≈øome few ≈øimple hearted ones into there ≈ønare, and pronounced them ble≈ø≈øed, ju≈øt as I have ≈øeene ≈øome do by little children, giving them counters to play with, and ≈øaying, or making them believe it was gold, ≈øo the≈øe pretended Prophets makes their di≈øciples to believe, that by their ≈øpeaking of a few words unto them, they do become the ble≈ø≈øed of God for ever; but on the contrary, if that any ≈øhould ≈øeem to neglect, or ≈ølight their commi≈ø≈øion, or ≈øhould not approve of their interpretation of ≈øcriptures, then they damne them to all eternity, whereby they have frighted, and terrified the hearts and ≈øpirits of ≈øome other ≈øimple hearted people; ju≈øt as the Church of Rome doth by their excommunications.

The Author of this ≈øhort Treati≈øe hearing of the≈øe men, who a≈ø≈øumed unto them≈øelves ≈øuch power, did de≈øire to be acquainted with them, and at the fir≈øt meeting, did aske them the≈øe three que≈øtions, viz.

list.item: 1. Whether God had the per≈øon of a man, and whether he had an audible voice?
2. Whether or no they could erre, or were incident to failings as other men were?
3. Whether or no they could write ≈øcriptures ≈øo good as tho≈øe, which are already written by Moy≈øes, the other Prophets, the Evangeli≈øts, and the Apo≈øtles?

div.p: To all which, they thus, or to the like effect an≈øwered.

To the fir≈øt, that God had an audible voice, and that he was in the per≈øon of a man from al eternity, and that there was not, is not, nor never ≈øhall be any other God but the ≈øame Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, which was born of the Virgin Mary, and ≈øuffered at Jeru≈øalem, and that the world and all things el≈øe, was only, and alonely made by him, and that when this Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt was incarnate, and in his minority, and at his ≈øufferings, and in the grave, then there was no God in heaven, nor in earth, the government of all things for that time being committed to Moy≈øes and Elias; and what≈øoever God ≈øhould be profe≈ø≈øed by any, they had power, both to cur≈øe, and to damne them and their profe≈ø≈øours.

To the ≈øecond, they plainly declared that they could not erre nor faile, and were both alike minded, for they had an infallible ≈øpirit, by the which they were able to di≈øcern all things: neither could any man deceive them, neither could any ≈øickne≈øs or any di≈øea≈øe ≈øeize upon their bodies, neither ≈øhould they ever commit any ≈øinne, neither at their death ≈øhould they have the like fear and trouble in the lea≈øt, as the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt had when he ≈øuffered.

To the third they an≈øwered, that Moy≈øes, the other Prophets and Apo≈øtles had never the like light given them, nor the like power in ≈øpirituall things as they had, they being under the third and la≈øt di≈øpen≈øation; as they terme it, the di≈øpen≈øation of the ≈øpirit, therefore able to write Scriptures more then they al, and that there hath not been any man the≈øe fourteen hundred years pa≈øt, that ever hath ≈øpoken truth, from or truely opened any text of ≈øcripture, till they received their Comi≈ø≈øion.
To all which, I thus reply:

I do believe and declare unto the whole world, that that eternall, everliving, and all ≈øufficient, only wi≈øe God, who had his being of him≈øelfe, and in him≈øelfe, ≈øending forth all things, as of, ≈øo from, him≈øelfe; and againe retracting or drawing all things into him≈øelfe againe, is not to be comprehended,
known, or declared to be what he is in his Eternall or E≈ø≈øentiall being; for how can the Mortall declare or make manife≈øt the Immortall; the Creature the Creator; for the pot at furthe≈øt onely manife≈øts that it is made, but doth not know his Maker, neither can it ≈øo much as know his voyce; Then how can mortall man know the voyce of the Immortall God, which makes the Rocks to rend in pieces? Ye how terrible was the voyce of God to the I≈øraelites at Mount Sinai, that they never de≈øired to hear it any more, wherefore they de≈øired that Mo≈øes might ≈øpeak with them, and not God any more?

And ≈øecondly, whereas they do declare, that they cannot ≈øin at all, nor erre at any time, nor fail in their judgements; I my ≈øelf with many others can witne≈ø≈øe ≈øeverall pa≈ø≈øages to the contrary, and let all rea≈øonable men judge if ra≈øh anger, ra≈øh judgement, cen≈øuring and back-biting be not ≈øinne: Again, I with many others is able to te≈øtifie again≈øt them to their faces, how they have failed and erred in judgement; for whereas they both affirmed that they were both endued, lighted, and guided by one and the ≈øelf-≈øame infallible ≈øpirit, that no man was able to deceive them, or go about it, but they ≈øhould be able to de≈øcern their hypocri≈øie or deceit.

They having in my hearing, and in the hearing of ≈øome others pronounced the ≈øentence of Damnation upon a man; I asked whether or no this ≈øentence could not be revok'd upon the parties humiliation and acknowledgement of his Errour; the one of them, to wit, Muggleton, an≈øwered it might; then I asked the other, to wit, Reeve, the ≈øame que≈øtion, and he an≈øwered and ≈øaid, It could not; by meanes whereof they did contend one again≈øt another, which ≈øhews they were of a different judgement: Again, the ≈øaid pretended Prophet Reeve having in my ≈øight with a many others pronounced the ≈øentence of ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs and ≈øalvation to a Gun≈ømith in the Minories, his fellow Prophet did within a quarter of an hour pronounce the ≈øentence of damnation upon the ≈øame party, and al≈øo the bla≈øting of his E≈øtate.

Again, not long ≈øince being in company with the fore≈øaid two pretended Prophets, and ≈øome other company, there came in a Gentleman whom they had damned three months before, or thereabouts; but the ≈øaid Gentleman not taking notice that ever he had ≈øeen them before, carrying him≈øelf very fairly and ≈øeemingly, did approve of their judgements, by which meanes he did obtain their good liking, in≈øomuch that they both declared they had nothing again≈øt him, but that he might have the Ble≈ø≈øing, whereupon the Gentleman called them a couple of Loger-heads, ≈øaying, Are you the Prophets of the Lord, & doth not know that ye have already ≈øentenced me to damnation, by all which (good people) ye may ≈øee their gro≈øs failings, and that they may be ≈øubject to ≈øin, errour, and mi≈øtakes, notwith≈øtanding their great boa≈øting, that if any ≈øhould come into their company whom before they had cur≈øed, they ≈øhould di≈øcern and know him, although he ≈øhould never ≈øo much di≈øgui≈øe him≈øelf.

And thirdly, the≈øe two pretended Prophets do not only a≈ø≈øume unto them≈øelves a Prerogative and power above and beyond Mo≈øes & the other Prophets and Apo≈øtles in the knowledge of the mind and wil of God in the Scriptures, but al≈øo that they can both adde to the≈øe Scriptures, and dimini≈øh from them, ≈øaying, What≈øoever they ≈øhall not approve of to be Scripture, is no Scripture at all, and ≈øo hath cut off all Salomons Writings, and the Book of Job to be any part of the Scripture, by means whereof there is a great ≈øtumbling block laid before the weak, who in the ≈øincerity of their hearts are ≈øeeking the Lord, and hath ever had the≈øe Books in e≈øteem, as all other Scripture; nay; and ≈øome have ≈øaid, that they may as well que≈øtion all the other Scriptures as the≈øe.

Now I would que≈øtion whether or no the≈øe men that thus adde to, and dimini≈øh at their plea≈øure from the word of God, be not ≈øuch as comes under that ≈øentence mentioned in the 22. of the Revel. Cur≈øed is every one that addes or dimini≈øhes from the words which are written in this Book, and ≈øo the plagues which are written therein to be ju≈øtly due unto them.

And likewi≈øe that the≈øe pretended Prophets may not be the ≈øame fal≈øe deceiving Prophets which our Lord and Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt bids u≈øe beware, and take heed of in the 7. of Matth. ver. 15. therefore I have here in≈øerted their Tenets as followeth.

div.head: Severall Tenets holden by the≈øe pretended Prophets.
div.p: 1. THe God whom they wor≈øhip and ≈øerve hath not onely an Audible voyce, but al≈øo the body of a man di≈øcribing him to be a little ≈øhorter then the Authour of this Book, and a little taller then the ≈øaid Prophet Reeve, nay he was the pitch of a yong Gentleman whom they have ble≈ø≈øed.

2. That there is a place or Earth above the ≈øtarrs, wherein this bodily God doth re≈øide, and out of which he created this naturall Earth upon which we live, and that in that upper or Firmamentall Earth there are Seas, with all maner of Fi≈øhes, and that there is all manner of Bea≈øts and Fowls, and there is the place or habitation of the ble≈øsed Angels, as al≈øo of the Saints afore≈øaid.
3. That the body and ≈øoul doth both depart this life, and dye together, and ≈øo continueth unto the Re≈øurrection.
4. That after the Generall Re≈øurrection this Earth upon which we now live ≈øhall be a place whereupon all the damned ≈øhall re≈øide and be tormented for ever.

5. This ≈øhall be the torment wherewith the ≈øaid damned ≈øhould be tormented, that their body ≈øhould be as Brim≈øtone, and their ≈øpirit as fire, there to burn and be tormented for ever; and that there ≈øhould be no outgoing nor incomming of any of the ≈øences, whereby they ≈øhould have the lea≈øt comfort or plea≈øure in any thing.

6. Whereas ≈øome have declared, and a many more may declare, that they have received the a≈ø≈øurance to them≈øelves of Gods Love in Je≈øus Chri≈øt; yet the≈øe doth declare, that it is nothing, nor of no worth, if they ≈øhould declare the contrary, whereby they make them≈øelves to be above God him≈øelf.

7. That who≈øoever did not work for them, were (all ≈øure as there were a God in Heaven) damn'd to all Eternity: There being once an old man in company whom they had formerly damd ≈øpoke to the Prophet Reeve to fall to his work again, he did plainly declare in the hearing of a many, that as ≈øure as there was a God in heaven, who≈øoever did not work for them was damn'd to all eternity; further ≈øaying, Old man there's a doctrine for you.

8. That mo≈øt of all tho≈øe who had drawn the Sword in the≈øe warrs, were as ≈øure as there was a God in Heaven, damn'd to all Eternity, and that Generall Cromwell him≈øelf if he ≈øhould de≈øpi≈øe their Commi≈ø≈øion, they would pronounce him a damn'd Reprobate.
9. That all Mini≈øters, Lawyers, Phy≈øitians, and who≈øoever goeth to Law, or who≈øoever taketh Phy≈øick for the recovery of their healths, are in the ≈øtate of damnation.
10. That all tho≈øe whom they damn in this world ≈øhould never neither in this world; nor in the world to come, ≈øee, or know any other Gods but them.

11. That who≈øoever they declared, or ≈øentenced to be ble≈ø≈øed, ≈øhould daily more and more encrea≈øe in faith, and more and more daily ≈øhould have power over ≈øin; and at a time, one whom they bad ble≈ø≈øed, declaring plainly that he had not as yet found any ≈øuch effects wrought on him, they told him that their faith ≈øhould uphold him till he had received faith of his own.

12. One asking them how they ≈øhould attain to their faith; they told him, that they mu≈øt ca≈øt away al Ordinances, as praying, hearing, and the like, and beleeve them to be tho≈øe two Prophets before-mentioned ≈øent of God.
13. If that God ≈øhould not maintain them without working, they would never ≈øerve ≈øuch a God.
14. That their God is wi≈øer, and knoweth more to day then ye≈øterday, and ≈øo continually encrea≈øeth in wi≈ødom & knowledge.
15. That the Judges of this Land together with the Mini≈øters and Magi≈øtrates are tho≈øe that ≈øhall be ca≈øt into the Lake alive.
16. If they ≈øhould be brought before Authority for this their judgement or practice, they ≈øhould not be half ≈øo fearfull to ≈øuffer death as Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf was.

I have al≈øo often ob≈øerved one cheating trick or Policie of the≈øe la≈øt 2 pretended Prophets, That when any came to rea≈øon with them; and to put them to it, they would pre≈øently pronounce the ≈øentence of damnation again≈øt ≈øuch a one, meerly to ≈øhun all manner of Di≈øcour≈øe with ≈øuch; ≈øaying, That they were not to rea≈øon, or bold Conferrence with the damned.

Now I come to a conclu≈øion, and therefore in the feare of God, and all tenderne≈ø≈øe of affection, I would entreat all people to be carefull, and take heed of all ≈øuch fal≈øe deceiving and deluding ≈øpirits, which comes forth with ≈øuch Me≈ø≈øages to damn and to cur≈øe, and ≈øayes that they are ≈øent of God for that end and purpo≈øe, which in my judgement is one of the horride≈øt bla≈øphemies that ever I heard of, and a doctrine ≈øo contrary to the tenor of the whole Go≈øpel; for our Lord and Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt in the 5. Chapter of Matthew, pronounces many ble≈ø≈øings, but the≈øe two ≈øaith, That no ble≈ø≈øing of God ≈øhall be available upon any that ≈øhall in the lea≈øt gain≈øay them, the power of ble≈ø≈øing and cur≈øing being committed to them as the In≈øtruments of God for that purpo≈øe; and this al≈øo is far contrary to Pauls Doctrine, who ≈øaith, Ble≈øs and cur≈øe not, knowing that ye are thereunto called, and it hath been ever the property of all Saints in all Ages, when≈øoever they came to the knowledge, that they them≈øelves were ble≈ø≈øed of God, not onely to refrain from Cur≈øing, but even with all their hearts and ≈øouls, to Ble≈øs, and to rejoyce them≈øelves in Ble≈ø≈øing; but I have known the≈øe two pretended Prophets with all eagerne≈ø≈øe and bitterne≈ø≈øe of ≈øpirit, to double, and redouble their Cur≈øes upon ≈øome, calling them Devills, and Reprobated Devils, meerly for not approving their judgements; and therefore for my owne part, I leave them to the judgement of tho≈øe who ≈øhall have occa≈øion to try them hereafter; And ≈øo I conclude with the≈øe following Ver≈øes:

div.head: ¬∂ Here followeth ≈øome Ver≈øes of the Authors upon the word BROTHER, to one he ≈øo called in London.

lg.l: B BLe≈øt is that Light, that whom≈øoere doth ≈øee,
Doth weare the Crown of Immortalitie.
In this Light life is, and no death at all;
There's all rejoycings, there's no Funerall.
R RUn through the world you body, blood & bone,
Take Scen≈øes with you, and you eight, makes one;
Yet were your eight 10000 eight times more,
Ye were no neerer then you were before.
O O How the Light rejoyceth in it ≈øelf,
It hath no re≈øpect to your worldly pelfe,
It doth not grow, nor doth it ere decline,
It knows no degree between thine and mine.
T THe Darkne≈ø≈øe judges all things to be light,
How can this be, when they are meer dark night?
Unle≈ø≈øe it be as I beleeve and ≈øay,
That they do ≈øpeak it out of a dark day.
H HE that's in Light, the light and he is one,
He through the Father ≈øhineth like the Son:
World evermore, his glory is ≈øo great,
That Men and Angels can it not repeat.
E EVen ≈øo the Darkne≈ø≈øe ever loves it ≈øelf,
That it will part from all things, even from pelf
To uphold its Kingdom, and its glory keep,
It will u≈øe all formes, it will pray, preach, fa≈øt, & weep.
R REnowned Bli≈ø≈øe, to Thee be ever pray≈øe,
For in thy Light is our full Length of Dayes;
We joy in Thee, our joy is in no other,
And ≈øo I end as I began, Dear Brother.

div.head: ¬∂ To another Brother, who≈øe Name is Miles.

lg.l: M MY Mind's at re≈øt, ≈øeeing the Truth I finde,
That tho≈øe that ≈øay we ≈øee not, are ≈øtark blinde,
Then judge ye all ye wi≈øe men I be≈øeech,
If tho≈øe that follow blind men ≈øcape the Ditch.
I I Have known five before run in this ≈øtraine
Of Bla≈øphemy, yet all their ends prov'd vain;
And now at la≈øt comes Muggleton and Reeve,
That to delude them≈øelves do wholly give.
L LOrd keep thy Servants in thy love ≈øo great,
From tho≈øe deluders and their fond conceit,
That none of thine in them may put their tru≈øt,
Nor ≈øuch fal≈øe gods as alwayes are unju≈øt.
E EVery Age brings forth all kind of things,
As harmle≈øs Lambs, & Serpents which have ≈øtings,
And holy Ones, who ≈øerves with filiall fear,
And Prophets fal≈øe, who do God cur≈øe and tear.
S SO that the≈øe Locu≈øts can not be the fir≈øt,
Sent late from God, as vermin to be cur≈øt;
And though in a ≈øhort time God may them bla≈øt,
I could de≈øire that they may be the la≈øt.
SSS Take one S more, and ≈øo make even,
And in tho≈øe four can ye not find out Stephen?
If not, let the≈øe my Ver≈øes be allow'd,
Find you but Stephen in Love, and I'le be Proud:
Howe're let not my Ver≈øes go to wrack,
Although begot under my Pedling Pack.

div.head: Here followes ≈øome certain Ver≈øes, pen'd by the Author, who hath ≈øeen, and knowne, three or four couples, who hath called them≈øelves Prophets upon the ≈øame account.

lg.l: I Speak the truth within the≈øe ≈øixteen year,
Three couple within our Hemi≈øphere;
And all three couple ≈øay, they came from God,
From this ≈øame Text, To plague us with his Rod.
The fir≈øt two Prophets out of E≈ø≈øex came,
Weavers by Trade, Farnam and Bull by name;
They proudly ≈øaid, that we all pray'd in vain,
For till their plea≈øure was, it ≈øhould not rain.
Yet „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øome „Äà‚óä‚óä„Äâ blinde,
The knavery of tho≈øe two, did quickly finde,
Farnam to Newgate they did ≈øend to preach,
And Bull in Old-Bridewell there mu≈øt teach.
So that between Newgate, and Bridewels whipping-Post,
The≈øe Prophets quickly both their Faiths had lo≈øt;
Then tho≈øe ≈øilly ones whom they had led herein,
When they ≈øaw this, Cry'd Lord great is our ≈øin.
The other two bla≈øphemers from the Text,
Was Robbins, and Garment, they came next;
And we have witne≈ø≈øe that Robbins oft hath ≈øayd,
That he hath power, both over quick and dead:
And he kept his di≈øciples at ≈øuch a bay,
That they to none, but to him≈øelfe ≈øhould pray;
And further ≈øaid, they ≈øhould not pray in vain,
For he the heavenly Manna would down rain.
Now the la≈øt two; is Reves and Muggleton,
That comes among≈øt us with their damning doom;
They ≈øay they will ≈øpare none great nor ≈ømall,
For if ye cro≈ø≈øe their way, they'le damn you all.
But this they ≈øay again to comfort you;
That if ye can believe that they are true,
What though ye ≈øin? ye need not to di≈øpaire‚ñ™
For they of Soul and Body both take care.
Now O ye Powers that bears the ≈øway
Under the true God, I do you obey,
And I de≈øire that ye the≈øe men would ≈øound,
And if in them the truth of God be found,
Let them be honored by you as is meet,
Pro≈øtrating your honours at their feet;
But if ye find them in your wi≈øedomes great,
A paire of Knaves; living upon deceit.
I pray you ≈øet them to their work againe,
And not idlely ≈øo to live on others paine;
There Trade is good, I ≈øpeak it as a friend,
For I am ≈øure they can both make and mend,
They on their Shop-board there may command all
Tho≈øe little creatures, red, white, black, and all,
And if the≈øe creatures chance for to rebell,

Then power they have to dam ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ in their hel.
